questions.text: 1. A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of frequent episodes of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. Her barium study is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain with a barium study showing a protrusion of a portion of the stomach through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm is suggestive of a hiatus hernia.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1 or sliding hernia - gastroesophageal junction migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD.

Type 2 or rolling hiatus hernia - gastroesophageal junction is normal in position but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features include dysphagia and chest pain. In severe cases, it can cause obstruction, strangulation, ischemia, perforation, and compression of the lungs, leading to impaired lung function.

Type 3 or mixed hiatus hernia - a combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia - other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Ex:- Colon.



Pearl PM2445: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance



Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.



Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.



Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.



Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.



Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.



Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.





Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 



Pearl PM1528: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

* Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

* Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

* Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)

* Regurgitation

* Chest pain

* Weight loss

* Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy



Pearl PM1527: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).



Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

* Hypopharyngeal

* False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat

* Acquired 

* Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

* Dysphagia

* Regurgitation

* Halitosis

* Aspiration

* Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).



It is treated with:

* Cricopharyngeal myotomy

* Surgical diverticulectomy

* Marsupialization

* Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: 2. A 50-year-old male patient is posted for TURP (transurethral resection of prostate) under subarachnoid block. Up to which dermatome must the anesthetist ensure adequate anesthesia?
questions.solution:
For procedures like TURP, the sensory block should be achieved up to the T10 dermatomal level, as the pain-sensitive peritoneum innervation starts from T10 level.

Dermatomal level of required sensory blocks for various common surgical procedures:

* T4 - Upper abdominal surgery, Cesarean section

* T10 - Transurethral resection of the prostate, Hip surgery

* L2 - Foot and ankle surgery

Pearl PM2126: Factors affecting dermatomal spread of spinal anesthesia

Factors affecting the dermatomal spread of spinal anesthesia
  More important Less important
Drug factor Dose Volume
Baricity Concentration
  Viscosity
  Additives
Patient factor CSF volume Weight
Advanced age Height
Pregnancy Spinal anatomy
  Intra-abdominal pressure
Procedure factor Patient position Level of injection
Epidural injection post spinal Needle orifice direction
  Needle type

questions.text:
3. A 34-year-old female patient on maintenance hemodialysis presents with exertional dyspnoea. Further evaluation reveals that her symptoms are due to a large arteriovenous fistula that was used for the hemodialysis. Which of the following physiologic changes are expected in this patient?

CO - Cardiac output

SVR - Systemic vascular resistance

VR - Venous return
questions.solution:
Correct option is A : CO (Cardiac output) ↑, SVR (systemic vascular resistance)  ↓, VR (Venous return) ↑

A large arteriovenous fistula allows for blood to bypass the resistance of the systemic arterioles leading to a reduced systemic vascular resistance (SVR) i.e decreased afterload. Low peripheral resistance allows blood to quickly return to the heart leading to increased venous return and a high preload. A combination of high preload and low afterload increases the cardiac output.

Excessively large fistulas can lead to high-output heart failure as the left ventricle fails to keep up with the increased venous return.

Few causes of high output cardiac failure include:

* Pagets disease

* Acquired or congenital arteriovenous fistula

* Severe anemia

* Thiamine deficiency

* Hyperthyroidism

questions.text:
4. A 60-year-old male with 30% body surface area burns is receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation. He later developed abdominal pain, swelling, marked distension, tense abdomen, bilateral lower extremity edema, and decreased urine output. Vitals are shown below. Bladder pressure was 22 cm H2O. What is expected in this patient?

Vital Signs  
Temperature 99°F
Pulse Rate 90/minute
Respiratory Rate 17/minute
Blood Pressure 140/90 mm Hg
SpO2 98% on room air
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of abdominal compartment syndrome. A decrease in cardiac preload is expected in this patient.

The increased intra-abdominal pressure (Option D) and intrathoracic pressure cause extrinsic venous compression, leading to elevated CVP. The compression also results in decreased IVC flow and decreased cardiac preload. This finally leads to decreased cardiac output (Option B), hypotension, and compensatory tachycardia. Abdominal wall compliance cannot increase in an acute setting (Option C).

Etiology:

* Trauma

* Liver transplantation

* Massive ascites, intraperitoneal bleeding, abdominal surgery, and other abdominal conditions

* Retroperitoneal pathology 

* Sepsis, which requires fluid resuscitation

* Post-surgical patients

Pathophysiological features:

* Impaired cardiac function

* Reduced venous return

* Elevated CVP and PCWP

* Increased peak and inspiratory airway pressures

* Renal vein compression and renal artery vasoconstriction

* Decreased intestinal perfusion

* Lactic acidosis

* Elevated ICP

Clinical features:

* Malaise, weakness, abdominal pain, abdominal bloating, lightheadedness, dyspnea

* Tensely distended abdomen

* Decreased urinary output

* Peripheral edema

* Hypotension

* Tachycardia

Diagnosis:

Measuring bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method for screening intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS)

Treatment:

Treatment includes rapid decompression of the elevated intra-abdominal pressure by opening the abdominal wound and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall with mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag).

Abdominal compartment syndrome grading system based on bladder pressure:

Grade cm H2O
I 13-20
II 21 – 35
III 36 – 47
IV > 48


Increased stroke volume (Option 2) will not be seen in a patient with abdominal compartment syndrome because there will be a decreased preload and cardiac output, thereby. Abdominal wall compliance (Option 3) cannot increase in an acute setting. There is a marked increase in intra-abdominal pressure (Option 4) in compartment syndrome, not a decrease.

Pearl PM1772: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

* Cardiac output

* Venous return

* Visceral blood ﬂow

* Renal blood ﬂow

* Glomerular filtration

Increased :

* Cardiac rate

* Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

* Peak inspiratory pressure

* Central venous pressure

* Intrapleural pressure

* Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: 5. A 40-year-old HIV-positive man on treatment presents with white, corrugated, non-scrapable, painless, and non-bleeding plaques on his tongue, as shown below, for two weeks. Which of the following viruses is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes oral hairy leukoplakia. It occurs due to reactivation of the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection.

* Clinical Feature (OHL): HIV-infected patient presenting with a white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 

* Predisposing factors: Immunodeficiency, hematological malignancies, and steroid abuse can also be seen in immunocompetent individuals. 

* Investigations: Investigations show high levels of EBV DNA in the blood with circulating antibodies against VCA and early antigen (EA)‐restricted proteins.

* Pathology: Epstein–Barr virus replicates in maturing epithelial cells but is not present in basal and parabasal keratinocytes.

* Other conditions associated with EBV infection are

* Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis): fever, pharyngitis, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy

* Hodgkin lymphoma

* Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

* Burkitt's Lymphoma

* Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

* EBV‐associated lymphoproliferative disease



Other white lesions of the oral mucosa:

* Lichen planus

* Discoid lupus erythematosus

* White spongy nevus

* Candidiasis

* Leukoplakia

Malignancy risk:

* High-risk lesions

* Erythroplakia (homogenous or speckled).

* Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia.

* Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis

* Medium-risk lesions

* Oral submucous fibrosis

* Syphilitic glossitis

* Low-risk/equivocal risk lesions

* Oral lichen planus

* Discoid lupus erythematosus

* Discoid keratosis congenita

questions.text: 6. A 40-year-old woman presented with facial weakness and the following sign 4 days after undergoing total thyroidectomy. The probable cause of this condition includes all of the following except:

choices.text: Accidental ligature of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing carpopedal spasm are suggestive of hypocalcemia secondary to postoperative hypoparathyroidism. Thyroid insufficiency does not manifest with hypocalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism is a rare complication of thyroidectomy, which can occur as a transient event or due to the accidental removal of the parathyroid gland or ligation of the inferior thyroid artery. 

A rapid influx of serum calcium into bones in the immediate postoperative period may cause severe hypocalcaemia—hungry bone syndrome. It is more commonly observed in patients with beta-blockers. It is due to a sudden drop in PTH level after surgery.

Mostly, it is temporary due to vascular spasm of the parathyroid glands, which occurs on the 2nd-5th postoperative day.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

* Mild circumoral or digital numbness

* Paresthesia

* Laryngeal spasms 

* Cardiac arrhythmias 

* Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.

* Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (as shown in the image)

* Muscle weakness is the earliest feature of hypocalcemia.

* Convulsions

Serum calcium estimation is done, and then 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given intravenously 8th hourly. Later supplemented by oral calcium carbonate 500 mg 8th hourly. After 3–6 weeks, the patient is admitted, the drug is stopped, and the serum calcium level is repeated.

questions.text: 7. A 58-year-old female patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding her prognosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows immunohistochemistry staining negative for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors, which is a triple-negative or basal type of breast cancer. It has the worst prognosis among all the molecular subtypes.

Immunohistochemistry staining:

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

* The estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors; hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.

* The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor; hence, the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.



Molecular subtypes  ER PR  HER2 Ki-67 Cytokeratin 5 and 6

Luminal A

(Most common type and has the best prognosis) 

 +ve +ve -ve Low -ve
Luminal B +ve +ve +ve High -ve
  +ve +ve +ve Any -ve
HER2 enriched -ve -ve +ve Any -ve

Basal-like or Triple-negative breast cancer

(Aggressive, has worst prognosis but shows good response to chemotherapy, high PCR rates) 

 -ve -ve -ve Any +ve

Unclassified, now also known as Claudin-low 

 -ve -ve -ve Any -ve


Pearl PM2185: Molecular classification of breast cancer

 

Molecular subtypes 

Receptor status

Histological subtypes

Luminal A type 

(most common, best prognosis)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

<14% (low)

Lobular carcinoma

Mucinous carcinoma

Tubular carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2/neu negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2 

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

>14% (high)

Poorly differentiated, lobular-carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2 positive)

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- +ve

Ki-67- 

variable

  

HER2 enriched

Mutated gene- TP53

ER/PR- -ve

Her2- +ve

Ki-67- 

High 

Apocrine carcinoma

Micro-papillary carcinoma

 

Basal type (Triple-negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 1

ER/PR- -ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

High

Medullary carcinoma

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

Secretory carcinoma

Metaplastic carcinoma


*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

* ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.

* HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.

* ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

ER-positive, HER2- negative

  		 ER-positive, HER2- negative

HER2- Positive (ER- positive or negative)

ER- negative

HER2- negative

Frequency

~40-55% (Low proliferation)

~10% (High proliferation)

~20%

~15%

Included special histologic types

Well or moderately differentiated lobular, tubular, mucinous

Poorly differentiated lobular

Some apocrine

Medullary, adenoid cystic, secretory, metaplastic

Typical patient groups

Older women, men, cancers detected by mammographic screening

BRCA2 mutation carriers

Young women, non-white women, TP53 mutation carrier (ER-positive)

Young women, BRCA1 mutation carriers, African American and Hispanic women

questions.text:
8. A 40-year-old woman presents with fever and colicky right upper quadrant pain and tenderness in the same area. After further investigations, a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made. The patient is taken for the procedure shown in the below image. Which of the following physiological changes is not expected during this procedure?

CVP- Central venous pressure

FRC- Functional residual capacity

ICP-Intracranial pressure
questions.solution:
An increase in pH is not expected during this procedure.

The patient is undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and the pH during the procedure decreases due to the absorption of CO2, which in turn causes metabolic acidosis.

The physiological effects of CO2 pneumoperitoneum are categorized into two main areas: gas-specific and pressure-specific. When CO2 is rapidly absorbed into the circulation from the peritoneal membrane, it generates carbonic acid, leading to respiratory acidosis.

Initially, body buffers, primarily located in bone, absorb CO2 (up to 120 L) during short endoscopic procedures, minimizing hypercarbia or respiratory acidosis. However, once these buffers become saturated, respiratory acidosis develops quickly. At this point, the respiratory system becomes responsible for managing the absorbed CO2 and its release from the buffers.

Laparoscopic surgeries are performed by introducing a rigid laparoscope through a port into the peritoneal cavity. Carbon dioxide is insufflated into the abdominal cavity to create a pneumoperitoneum. The other laparoscopic instruments used for dissection are introduced via other surgically created ports.

There are two methods for establishing abdominal access during laparoscopic surgeries. One is the direct puncture technique, and the other is the direct peritoneal access technique.

There is evidence to show that laparoscopic surgery has short-term benefits over open surgery. Laparoscopic surgery has a better outcome with regard to postoperative pain, length of stay, and earlier return to normal activities.

The physiological changes during laparoscopic surgery occur mainly due to two reasons:

* creation of pneumoperitoneum

* position of the patient during surgery.

Physiological Effects of Laparoscopy

  

Cardiovascular

• ↑ Intra-abdominal pressure leads to ↑ CVP, ↑ PCWP, ↑SVR, and ↑ MAP, which further ↓ Preload and ↑ Afterload, ultimately decreasing cardiac output

Pulmonary

• Cephalad shift of the diaphragm decreases FRC, chest wall compliance, and tidal volume, increasing the work of breathing

• Hypercapnia leading to an increase in respiratory rate further adds to this.

Renal

• Increased IAP decreases renal flow, decreases GFR, and reduces urine output.

• Raised pCO2 leads to RAAS stimulation. No long-term change in GFR/UO.

Gastrointestinal
  • Decreased perfusion to the intestines and stomach (as a result of increased IAP) decreases pH
  • Decreased portal and hepatic flow leads to elevation of LFTs.

Peripheral vascular

• Incidence of DVT, PE is generally lower post-laparoscopic procedures, probably secondary to improved prophylaxis

• Risk is increased with longer procedures and the reverse Trendelenberg position.

Central nervous system

The intracranial pressure rises due to compression of the lumbar venous plexus, hypercarbia causing cerebral vasodilation due to carbon dioxide (CO2) insufflation, and inferior vena cava compression inhibiting cerebral venous drainage.

questions.text: 9. Damage to the genitofemoral nerve during surgery would result in all of the following, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the mons pubis and labium majus in females
Loss of sensation over the root of penis in males
Loss of sensation over the anteromedial skin of the thigh

questions.solution:
Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females and loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males. The genitofemoral nerve also innervates the cremaster muscle via the genital branch and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex.

Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve causes loss of sensation at the root of the penis and adjacent parts of the scrotum. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.



The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too.

If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also be injured following appendicectomy.

questions.text: 10. An open splenectomy is planned for a patient. The procedure involves ligating and dividing the short gastric vessels. Which of the following structures contains these vessels?
questions.solution:
The gastrosplenic ligament contains the short gastric vessels, which are ligated in an open splenectomy.

The gastrosplenic ligament runs from the hilum of the spleen to the greater curvature of the stomach. It contains the short gastric vessels, left gastroepiploic artery, associated lymphatics, and sympathetic nerves. In an open splenectomy, the gastrosplenic ligament is opened, and the short gastric vessels are ligated and divided.

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

Splenic ligament Attachments Contents
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon -
Phrenicosplenic ligament The undersurface of the diaphragm to the spleen -
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney Tail of the pancreas
Splenic artery and vein
Gastrosplenic ligament The greater curvature of the stomach to the upper pole of the spleen Short gastric vessels
Left gastroepiploic artery




Pearl PM1128: Peritoneal folds and their contents

The following table shows various peritoneal folds (omenta, mesenteries and ligaments) and their contents.

Peritoneal fold

Content

Lesser omentum

a)    Hepatoduodenal ligament 

b)    Hepatogastric ligament 

 

Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Right and left gastric vessels

Greater omentum (along the greater curvature of the stomach)

Right and left gastro-epiploic vessels

Gastrosplenic ligament

Short gastric and left gastro-epiploic branches of splenic artery

Gastrophrenic ligament

Left inferior phrenic artery

Gastrocolic ligament

Right gastroepiploic artery

Splenorenal/Lienorenal ligament

Splenic vessels. Also contains the tail of the pancreas

Mesentery

Jejunal and ileal branches of superior mesenteric artery

Transverse mesocolon

Middle colic vessels

Sigmoid mesocolon

Sigmoid and superior rectal vessels

questions.text: 11. A patient with an ulcer shown in the image below is admitted to the general surgery ward. A history of which of the following would you be likely to elicit in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ulcer with an undermined edge, which is seen in tuberculosis and could be associated with a preceding history of chronic cough and weight loss. 

Other options:

Option A: Unprotected sexual intercourse may be a significant history pointing towards syphilis which causes an ulcer with punched-out edges and wash-leather slough.

Option B: Exposure to UV radiation suggests the development of skin cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma has everted edges and basal cell carcinoma has rolled-out edges.

Option D: Diabetes mellitus causes neuropathic/trophic ulcer with punched-out edges.

questions.text: 12. A 50-year-old female with MEN2A develops a lump in her thyroid gland. Given below is the histologic image of the thyroid biopsy of this patient. The cells causing this tumour originate from?
questions.solution:
The cells from which this tumour originates are derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch.

The above histologic biopsy image of a patient with MEN2A  shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is said to arise from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. During embryological development, these cells originate from the neural crest cells and the ultimobranchial body of the fourth pharyngeal pouch.

The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

The 4th pharyngeal pouch develops a small diverticulum medial to the main pouch called the ultimobranchial body. The ultimobranchial body is later incorporated into the thyroid gland, and its cells give rise to the parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland. These cells secrete a hormone called calcitonin that is involved in the regulation of the calcium level in the blood.

The following are the derivatives of each pharyngeal pouch, respectively.

1st Pouch
  • Tympanic cavity (middle ear cavity)
  • Auditory tube (eustachian tube) 
2nd Pouch
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Tonsillar fossa
3rd Pouch
  • Inferior parathyroid glands 
  • Thymus
4th Pouch
  • Superior parathyroid glands 
  • Ultimobranchial body - gives rise to parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid gland




The parafollicular C-cells are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.



Note: Some researchers believe that the ultimobranchial body originates from the fifth pharyngeal pouch, but the fifth pharyngeal pouch is short-lived, and it ultimately incorporates into the fourth pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: 13. A 32-year-old man is found to have right-sided colon cancer. His father had similar colon cancer and died at the age of 40. His paternal aunt suffers from endometrial cancer and his paternal uncle also suffers from urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lynch syndrome or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and mismatch repair is the defective DNA repair mechanism here. 

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc. It is the most common cause of the syndromic form of colon cancer. Colon cancers are seen at younger ages and usually on the right side.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

Other options:

Option A: Defects in the nucleotide excision repair pathway are seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option B: Defects in non-homologous end-joining are seen in patients with subacute combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Defects in DNA base excision repair are seen in patients with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP) syndromes.

Pearl PM1256: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

* Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two

* At least two successive generations affected

* At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years

* Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.

* Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

Pearl PM1063: DNA Repair Mechanisms

Damaging agents Damage caused Repair mechanisms

Ionizing radiation

X-rays

Anti-tumor drugs

Double-strand breaks

Single-strand breaks

Intrastrand crosslinks

Interstrand crosslinks

 Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ)

UV light

Chemicals

Bulky adducts

Pyrimidine dimers

 Nucleotide excision repair (NER)

Oxygen radicals

Hydrolysis 

Alkylating agents

Abasic sites single-strand breaks

8-oxoguanine lesions

 Base excision repair (BER)
Replication errors

Bases mismatch

Insertions

Deletions

 Mismatch repair (MMR)


Pearl PM1064: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: 14. A cholecystectomy is performed on a 47-year-old obese female with gall stones. The specimen shows the presence of non pigmented stones as shown below. These calculi are most likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows non pigmented cholestrol gallstones, which can be seen in hyperlipidemia syndromes.

Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.

There are two main types of gallstones:

* Cholesterol stones, which consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

* Pigment stones, made of bilirubin calcium salts

Options A, B, and C: Chronic hemolytic syndromes, ileal resection, and biliary infection can cause pigment stones.

Pearl PM1438: Types of Gallstones

  • Advancing age
  • Female
  • Oral contraceptives and pregnancy
  • Obesity and insulin resistance
  • Rapid weight reduction
  • Gallbladder stasis
  • Dyslipidemia syndromes
  
  • Chronic hemolysis 
  • Ileal resection
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency
  Chronic biliary infection

Appearance

Pale yellow, round to ovoid, finely granular, hard external surface

Transection: glistening radiating crystalline palisade

> 1.5 cm in diameter, friable speculated and molded

Large, brown, laminated and soft

Constituents

Cholesterol, phospholipids, bile salts

Calcium bilirubinate

Calcium bilirubinate

questions.text: 15. A 20-year-old patient admitted with enteric fever developed intestinal perforation and was taken up for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following findings would you see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Typhoid/enteric fever causes longitudinal ulcers. Typhoid is the most common cause of ileal perforation in tropical countries.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop:

* Distension

* Diarrhea

* Splenomegaly

* Characteristic rose spots on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis

Surgical complications of typhoid are:

* Paralytic ileus

* Intestinal hemorrhage

* Free ileal perforation (characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness)

* Cholecystitis

* Longitudinal ulcers (usually situated in the distal ileum)

Diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool.

Treatment is with antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol. 

Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer. Intestinal resection is usually avoided. In unstable patients with evidence of septic shock, the bowel should be exteriorized and the perforation closed after recovery. Paratyphoid infection also resembles typhoid fever and is treated in a similar manner. 

Note: Transverse ulcers with stricture formation are seen in tuberculosis.

The image below shows Rose spots in a patient with enteric fever.

questions.text: 16. A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of a lesion in the lower eyelid. She says that the lesion was initially like a bump and now it is ulcerated. She is a farmer by occupation. On examination, an ulcerative lesion with raised and pearly white edge is seen in the lower eyelid of the right eye. The biopsy was taken from the lesion and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of cell nests. In the periphery of the cell nest, the cells are arranged in a palisading pattern. This is diagnostic of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the epithelial cells that arises from the basal layer of the epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore, it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized forms. The localized can be further divided into

* Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC

* Cystic

* Pigmented

* Naevoid.

Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests, accompanied by palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests. Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other options

Option A- Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns).

The microscopy of SCC consists of irregular masses of squamous epithelium. They may show keratin production.

Below image shows the microscopic appearance of SCC.



Option B- Marjolin's ulcer- It is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that appears on a pre-existing scar.

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum consists of multiple pink pruritic papules on the skin and mucous membranes with central umbilication. Microscopically it shows the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions in the cells of stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.

Below images show the macroscopic and microscopic appearance of molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: 17. A patient with traumatic injury to the skull is diagnosed to have an epidural hematoma. The area of impact is at the pterion, causing damage to the underlying artery. Which of the following foramen does this artery traverse through?
questions.solution:
Traumatic injury to the pterion can damage the underlying anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labeled as 3 in the image.

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

* Middle meningeal artery

* Nervus spinosus 

* Middle meningeal vein

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction that overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma. 

The four bones forming the pterion are:

* Frontal bone

* Squamous part of the temporal bone

* Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

* Parietal bone



The foramina marked in the image are:

1 - Foramen rotundum 2 - Foramen ovale 3 - Foramen spinosum 4 - Jugular foramen



Pearl PM2139: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits

  • Ophthalmic arteries

  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text:
18. A 30-year-old male presents to the ER after a road traffic accident. He is hypotensive and pale. The FAST scan reveals massive intraabdominal bleeding. He receives 4 units of packed red blood cell transfusion in the next hour. Which of the following complications can be expected in this patient?

* Hypercalcemia

* Hyperkalemia

* Hypokalemia

* Hypermagnesemia

* Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient who received 4 units of packed red blood cell transfusion (pRBCs) in 1 hour indicates massive blood transfusion. The expected electrolyte abnormalities in a massive blood transfusion are -

* Hypocalcemia

* Hyperkalemia

* Hypokalemia

* Hypomagnesemia

* Metabolic acidosis

* Metabolic alkalosis

* Hypothermia

* Coagulopathy

Pearl PM1492: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: 19. According to the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist, which of the following is carried out after anesthesia has been induced?

choices.text: Assess risk of allergy, aspiration and blood loss

questions.solution:
Prophylactic antibiotic administration is checked in the presence of the surgeon, anesthetist, and nurse, after induction of anesthesia, before the incision of the skin.

 

The WHO surgical safety checklist was developed to decrease errors and increase teamwork during surgery. It contains 19 items that have to be performed by the surgeon, anesthetist, and nurse during surgery.

Before induction of anesthesia, the anesthetist and nurse should check for the:

* Patient’s identity, site of procedure, procedure name, and consent.

* If the site of the surgery is marked.

* Working of the anesthesia machine and pulse oximetry.

* Check the medications.

* Risk of allergy, aspiration, and blood loss in the patient.

Before the incision of the skin, the surgeon, anesthetist, and nurse should:

* Introduce themselves by name and their role.

* Reconfirm the patient’s name, procedure, and site of incision.

* Check if the antibiotic prophylaxis has been given to the patient.

* Check if the essential imaging is displayed.

* Discuss the anticipated critical events.

Before the patient leaves the operating room, the nurse should verbally confirm:

* Name of the procedure.

* Counts of the instruments, sponges, and needles.

* Labelling of the specimen in front of the surgeon and anesthetist.

questions.text: 20. A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with diabetic ketoacidosis. He is a known case of heart failure and diabetes mellitus and is on medications. On examination, the below finding was noted as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is the likely cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a diabetic, heart failure patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis and the image showing Fournier's gangrene are suggestive of canagliflozin as the likely causative drug.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter, which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose.

It inhibits glucose reabsorption, resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in the blood glucose level. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors have a cardioprotective effect resulting from improved cardiac cell metabolism, improvement of the ventricular loading mechanism, and reduction of cardiac cell necrosis and fibrosis. It also has a renoprotective property.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. Fournier's gangrene is also one of the important adverse effects.

There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A- Acarbose is an α-glucosidase inhibitor that inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme in the brush border epithelium of the intestine and reduces the absorption of starch, dextrin, and disaccharides. The most important adverse effects are malabsorption, flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal bloating. Hypoglycemia can occur when it is given along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

Option C- Metformin belongs to the biguanide class of hypoglycemic drugs that activate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and reduce hepatic glucose production. The most common adverse effects of metformin include anorexia, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, vitamin B12 deficiency, and lactic acidosis. Metformin should be used cautiously in renal failure patients.

Option D- Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones class of hypoglycemic drugs that stimulate the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ) in muscle, fat, and liver, and reduce insulin resistance.

The most common adverse effects include weight gain and edema due to an increase in adiposity and fluid retention. They can increase the incidence of heart failure and the risk of fractures. Some cases of macular edema have been reported.

Pearl PM1497: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

 Function not known Brain, spleen, leucocytes
GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver
